awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Revolutionizing the Menopause Marketplace: The Potential of Cooling Jewelry to Provide Non-Medicinal Relief for Hot Flashes and Night Sweats
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commerical impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to provide an alternative to hormone replacement therapy for women going through menopause. The technical design and integration are unique in that the end product will operate in the form of hydro-activated, fashion jewelry. This product offers a discreet, stylish, and efficient solution for mitigating vasomotor symptoms, allowing women to remain comfortable as they go through menopause without having to resort to medications with unpleasant side effects. Additionally, the technology has the potential to positively impact the well-being of adjacent groups who suffer from other conditions that lead to overheating. The research and development of this product will increase access to health and wellness options for patients adversely affected by health challenges around the globe.
 
The proposed project seeks to advance the knowledge and understanding of evaporative cooling for use in wearable tech applications. The primary purpose of this research is to provide external cooling relief, via a passive-tech fashion accessory, to individuals experiencing vasomotor symptoms or overheating in general. The goals of the project include improving the efficacy and timing of cooling, while overcoming perception challenges that can vary by individual user experiences. Furthermore, new materials will be explored to further enhance the cooling sensation with testing and optimization being a consistent factor. Finally, customer feedback will be gathered regarding product efficacy and marketability. Upon completion, this research will provide a greater understanding of how to optimize and refine the evaporative cooling technology for wearable tech applications, leading to improved consumer satisfaction. Knowledge and understanding of evaporative cooling for use outside of the typical, large-scale industrial and residential home applications will be advanced and utilized for the proposed application.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The NSF SBIR Phase I project conducted by Fria LLC focused on developing and testing an innovative cooling bracelet designed to provide localized temperature relief, particularly for menopausal women experiencing vasomotor symptoms.

The research encompassed a comprehensive evaluation of the cooling bracelet's three main components: the solid metal part, the absorbent pad, and potential liquids for evaporative cooling. The study began with an extensive analysis of potential cooling liquids, considering safety, effectiveness, and availability. After thorough evaluation, water was identified as the most suitable option for prolonged skin contact and vapor exposure, based on guidelines from health agencies such as the CDC and NIH. Material testing of the bracelet's solid components revealed promising results. The brass component demonstrated excellent thermal properties, with a thermal conductivity of 120 W/m.K, significantly higher than air (0.025 W/m.K). This allows the bracelet to act as an extended fin, providing cooling even without evaporative effects when the external air temperature is lower than skin temperature. Four types of commercially available absorbent materials were tested for water absorptivity and cooling capacity. The black material showed the highest water absorptivity at 1.98 g/in², with a corresponding cooling capacity of 3.98 kJ per square inch. Cooling power tests under forced evaporation conditions, simulating an active wearer, ranged from 0.126 to 0.347 W/in², with the black material demonstrating the highest performance.

Thermal imaging tests revealed that the bracelet maintained skin temperature between two and five degrees celsius cooler than adjacent areas for over 20 minutes when using evaporative cooling. Non-evaporative cooling also provided a noticeable cooling effect through the extended surface technique and thermal storage in the brass component. The research identified three primary cooling mechanisms in the bracelet: evaporative cooling using water's latent heat of vaporization, extended surfaces (fin effect) for enhanced heat dissipation, and thermal storage utilizing the bracelet's materials. While the project successfully demonstrated the bracelet's effectiveness in providing localized cooling, several areas for future research were identified.

These include correlating thermal measurements to human comfort, exploring the use of phase change materials to enhance thermal storage, optimizing the design for passive cooling, evaluating heat transfer rates for each cooling mode, and assessing performance under various temperature and humidity conditions.

In conclusion, the Fria cooling bracelet has shown great promise as a non-medicinal solution for managing vasomotor symptoms, with potential applications extending to other markets requiring personal cooling solutions. The project has laid a solid foundation for further development and commercialization, bringing the company closer to providing an effective, non-invasive, EMF free wearable solution for temperature management and improved quality of life for individuals experiencing vasomotor symptoms.

 


Last Modified: 08/02/2024
Modified by: Sheilisa Mcneal
